fields.Name: X-Tack left in place
fields.ResponseText: An x-tack stitch on a blazer, jacket or skirt vent is meant to temporarily hold the fabric in shape, when worn it should be removed to allow for ease of movement.

fields.Name: White in Winter
fields.ResponseText: White is a color for all seasons.

fields.Name: Flip Flops Nice Dress
fields.ResponseText: Why take the time to create an elegant outfit only to ruin it with flip-flops? An outfit is a complete entity, from head to toe.

fields.Name: Skirt/Boots in October
fields.ResponseText: Winter is long enough already. Why rush to wear snow boots in still warm fall weather?

fields.EditorLetterHTML:
Fall/Winter Issue

Happy to Combat Sad

Thinking about the fall and especially winter months in Chicago in preparation for this issue, my mind inevitably wandered to the benefits and difficulties presented by Old Man Winter. Winter allows more time to spend in our respective hibernation stations; time to create, reflect, gather strength, and be with loved ones. But when the winter doldrums and cabin fever hits, usually in February and March, hibernation station and its inhabitants beg for open windows and fresh greenery to admire.

With winter come all sorts of emotions, Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) is one way to call this. Some of my fellow midwesterners get angry, others move away, and a few find coping methods for SAD like visits to local conservatories. Another method that I'm thinking about and focusing on for this issue is: Happy or "how apparel protects and pampers you."

In that spirit came the Mixing Seasons limit where participants incorporated elements from summer wardrobes into fall outfits, a learning experience that I hope we take into the winter months. Some of the other articles in this second issue touch upon what clothing does or does not do for us, how it goes beyond pampering or protecting.

It's important to remember that fashion is not only on our arms and legs but in our hands, we can control not only what we buy but how we use clothing, whether to uplift a mood or to save our heads and hands from blustering winds. Like one of my favorite characters from the Scottish television show, Still GameLong live protection and pampering!
fields.MissionStatement: Chic Shifter, a digital fashion journal with an altered hem, is a biannual publication that examines the fashion cultures of Chicago and builds a fashion-focused community within the city and larger Midwest. Chic Shifter deviates from mainstream fashion publications by giving priority to text over image. Addressing a lack of criticality in fashion publications, Chic Shifter creates and initiates dialogue around important issues in fashion; in other words, criticality over frivolity. Thus a Chic Shifter is an individual who shifts and transforms definitions of chic.

fields.EditorLetterHTML:
Spring/Summer Issue

“The Four R’s: Reduce, Reuse, Revive, Risk”

On a summer trip to the Adriatic coast in 1982, my mother had purchased several lovely dresses for me, all of which I adamantly refused to put on in favor of shorts and a t-shirt. My mother laughs and recalls that it was at this moment when she understood she couldn’t tell me what to wear, and has never tried to again. My initial refusal to wear dresses led to a later phase at the age of five of only wearing dresses with pants, a trusted ensemble that I still revert back to as a thirty-something.

Although I was never skilled with needle and thread for making clothes or pencil for sketching them, clothes and fashion have always been integral to my understanding of self and others. However, despite my love for fashion, mainstream fashion publications never fully engaged my fashion sensibilities. Until I found WORN Fashion Journal, a Canadian fashion magazine devoted to celebrating fashion for those that love fashion but hate mainstream fashion magazines. Unfortunately, I discovered it too late, as it had already gone out of print in 2014. Thus, I am creating Chic Shifter in this same rebellious spirit.

Likewise, books such as Women in Clothes and Fear and Clothing have shown me that I am not alone in my desire for critical dialogue about fashion. Roland Barthes, Georg Simmel, Adolf Loos, Jean Baudrillard, and Fashion Theory Journal also raise important questions about fashion theory and clothing that I will address within Chic Shifter with the desire to foster further conversation.

It is my hope that Chic Shifter will support a community of Midwesterners who are interested in learning about local designers, fashion exhibits, personal style and larger issues in the fashion world. As a Chicagoan, I have always respected and loved the working-class character of the city. Chicago is a tough city, the harsh weather can harden and invigorate. While the Chicago fashion sense tends to be defined as utilitarian, sensible, and comfortable; there are often careful details under the layers that play into a Midwestern aesthetic.

Chic Shifter is released biannually in keeping with a move towards the notion of a slow fashion. This first issue for Spring/Summer, focused on “Four R’s: Reduce, Reuse, Renew, Risk” tackles issues of sustainability, conscious consumption, and the cyclical versus innovative nature of fashion. These four R’s are essential in considering Spring/Summer fashions as we shed layers of protection from the fall and winter and move forward.

A chic shifter works to shift fashion from just a consumer’s passing folly to a thoughtful and concerned passion. Loving and supporting Chicago fashion, and that of the Midwest, Chic Shifter carves out a space for fashion criticism, and praise, all while dressed in whimsy and wit.

fields.Description: Touring Chic seeks out fashion exhibitions in the Midwest. This first tour led me to exhibits in Detroit, Toledo, Kent, and Indianapolis in December 2015. The exhibits Detroit D.Fined, Flapper Style, Inside Out , and Fashion Timeline run through 2016. Others have closed, but Touring Chic reminds us that chic is everywhere, it just needs to be discerned by a chic shifter.

fields.Name: Finding Order Within Fashion’s Disorder
fields.HTML:
Finding Order Within Fashion’s Disorder

by Ana Sekler

As much as the fashion industry presents itself in a state of constant flux, always innovating and offering different products, it can be liberating to think of fashion as existing within a system. Roland Barthes, the French literary theorist, linguist and philosopher, introduced a linguistic order within fashion in his book, The Fashion System, written in 1967.

Through Barthes’ semiotic analysis of clothing as written language, based on consulting issues of Elle and Le Jardin des Modes from June 1958–59, he argues that clothing shares with language the objective of communication. Barthes summarized his endeavor best in an interview with France-Forum in 1967:

“My book is an itinerary, a patient, almost meticulous voyage accomplished by an ingenuous man who tries to see how meaning is constructed, how men construct it—in this case, how fashionable clothing is made meaningful: thus, the book becomes a voyage of discovery, a topical itinerary of meaning. And yet this itinerary is presented not as a personal voyage but as a grammar, a description of levels of meaning, of units and their combinatory rules, in short, as a kind of syntax of description. The book will be justified if, being itself a composed object, it manages to evoke before the reader’s eyes, in a kind of homologous fashion, a new object which is clothing in the written mode.”

While many of the chapters in The Fashion System address this application of structural linguistics to dress, I will focus on only one idea: that of rhythm within fashion. I found it most relevant to my current thoughts on fashion, the first “R” in this issue that is reduce. The notion of a rhythm in fashion is introduced by Barthes when he touches upon the work of American cultural anthropologist, A.L. Kroeber, father of famed writer, Ursula K. Le Guin. Kroeber examined the principles that guided fashion from 1894–1919. The main premise of his work can be summed up by the following: “the rhythm of fashion change is not only regular (the amplitude is about a half century, complete oscillation takes a century) but tends to alternate forms according to a rational order; for example, the breadth of a skirt and that of the waistline are always in inverse relations: when one is narrow, the other is wide. In short, on a time scale of adequate duration, fashion is an orderly phenomenon, and this order comes from within fashion itself.”

According to Barthes, if this rhythm continues to be regular, then skirt length will lengthen from 1967 on and at about 2020 or 2025, skirts should be long again. I found this information fascinating as I do see evidence to corroborate. The midi-length skirt has been a recent hit and maxi dresses continue to dominate much of the summer wardrobe offerings in 2016, so it seems reasonable to postulate that long skirts will be all the rage in four years. Fashion is too often thought of in the span of a few years, but if the range of perception is broadened to thirty or forty years, then seeing a historical continuity is possible.

With each new season, designers are marketing the novel, the fresh and singular items that weren’t there the season before. It becomes even more complicated when today’s fashion introduces not two seasons a year, but eight or even 52 “micro-seasons.” How can fashions change so quickly? The careful observer will note that styles do not in fact change as fast as the industry would lead us to believe.

One of the juiciest attractions to a television series like Downton Abbey, set between 1912–25, is not only the twisting plot lines and character development, but also the fashions of a century ago. Contemporary designers took a cue and the 2012 lines of Gucci, Ralph Lauren, and Anna Sui evoked the rollicking twenties. The bob haircut was one of the most popular cuts of 2015, another throwback to the previous century.

Examples of the cyclical nature of fashion are to be found everywhere. The disco ball has landed in all its metallic glory of fringe, jumpsuits, and high-waists; the ‘70s returned with a roar in 2014, after over forty years. The sixties influence can be evidenced in Miu Miu’s most recent collections—patent leather and patterns galore in bright baby-blues, sunshine yellows, and Kelly greens. The eighties influence is already being seen, in today’s oversized denim jackets, mirrored sunglasses, and the cuffed jeans.

Fashion’s changes are not always easily reducible to a system as its language was for Barthes, but it is important to be aware of the regularity of trends so as not to fall prey to them each time they are marketed as “must have” or “season’s hottest.” There are plenty of fashion designers who are testing boundaries with their cutting-edge designs and truly offering a new idea. I’m reminded of Japanese designer, Kunihiko Morinaga’s brand Anrealage, who used photosensitive fabrics in his fall 2015 collection, which changed color when hit by spotlights on the runway, and Belgian fashion designer Iris van Herpen who has been working with 3D printing in her collections. On the other end of the spectrum, designers like local designer Leigh DeLeonardo offers quality-made classic garments that go beyond trend.

Although there are limits to Barthes’ linguistic model, as evidenced in Michael Carter’s 2012 article in Fashion Theory Journal, “Stuff and Nonsense: The Limits of the Linguistic Model of Clothing.” If we rely on this linguistic model we can ignore other discoveries. “Dress consists of material forms and is not just a notice board upon which are attached two-dimensional signs. Allowing for the profound conceptual transformations of clothing brought about by Barthes it is still not possible to wholly subsume clothing beneath the banner of communication,” writes Carter.

Barthes’ writing on fashion appeals to me because of its organization of a seemingly chaotic aspect of the everyday into a manageable structure. For me, clothing is more approachable and manageable when I set limits or work within an imaginary system even. For example, if I only seek out patterns when shopping then the experience becomes less overwhelming than having no idea of what I want, which is a limit in itself. With no idea of what is wanted, surprises or extreme frustration can ensue. Following fashion’s trends is a fruitless and consuming labor. Establishing one’s personal style, however, is timeless and rewarding. Yves Saint Laurent’s famous phrase comes to mind, “Fashions fade, style is eternal.”

fields.Name: Les collectionneurs / The collectors
fields.HTML:
Les collectionneurs /The collectors

by Ana Nezna

Ever since reading Women in Clothes, a book that sets out to examine not what women wear but the reasoning behind their choices, I’ve been more attentive to my own clothing behaviors. The book is a collection of essays, conversations, photographs, and surveys from more than 600 women. The authors, Sheila Heti, Heidi Julavits, and Leanne Shapton, sent out questionnaires to hundreds of women asking them a range of questions: “What is your cultural background and how has that influenced how you dress?” to “Are there any clothing (or related) items that you have in multiple?” The women who contributed to the book include Cindy Sherman, Lena Dunham, Kim Gordon, Tavi Gevinson, and Miranda July.

One section that I particularly enjoyed was “Collections,” a page of photographs devoted to documenting what various women collected, ranging from tote bags and nail polish to jean jackets and leopard-print tops. The collections were never discussed in any detail, but the pictures were so lovely to look at, nine gray sweatshirts, ten pairs of marled socks, thirteen navy blazers, alike and different in their own ways. It got me thinking about my own collections, was there a clothing item that I had in multiple?

I didn’t have to think long as I immediately remembered my own collection of striped shirts, mainly long-sleeved and a few short-sleeved, a collection I shared with one of the authors, Heidi Julavits. This led me to an endless list of questions: Why the striped shirts? When did I start collecting them? Why collect clothing? What do people in my social circle collect? Are collections treated differently from singular items? Do I care for my striped shirts more carefully than my one red dotted t-shirt?

Everyone collects; it’s a human activity. In Eric Rohmer’s film La Collectionneuse, Haydée collected lovers. In a 2014 article from The Guardian, “Why do we collect things? Love, anxiety, or desire,” Christian Jarrett, psychologist and author of The Rough Guide to Psychology, says “One psychoanalytical explanation for collecting is that unloved children learn to seek comfort in accumulating belongings; another is that collecting is motivated by existential anxieties – the collection, an extension of our identity, lives on, even though we do not. More recently, evolutionary theorists suggested that a collection was a way for a man to attract potential mates by signaling his ability to accumulate resources.”

Jean Baudrillard addressed collecting in his seminal text The System of Objects. He describes collecting as a type of organization in response to the ambiguity of our ordinary environment, “Collecting, however, offers a model here: through collecting, the passionate pursuit of possession finds fulfillment and the everyday prose of objects is transformed into poetry, with triumphant unconscious discourse.” He cites Maurice Rheims in likening collection to a “passionate game.” In thinking about my own collection of striped shirts, I could understand that I was not just seeking out any striped shirt, but that this collection had grown to be passionate in the sense that the shirts that made it into the collection were special and somehow heroic.

Inspired by Women in Clothes, I sent out a brief questionnaire to several friends, asking them what they collected, when they began collecting, why this particular item and if possible to provide a photo of their collections. Two friends responded.

Chris Roberts, a former artist formerly of Chicago who currently lives in Oakland, CA, is a collector. I know him as a collector of sunglasses, and was sure he would report on that, but instead he responded with another of his trademark items: the golfer cap. He’s been collecting them since 1997 and says, “Once I found my style, I just kept it.” Roberts, who says he’s often cold, needs the caps for warmth. He doesn’t take any special care of them and says “usually once they start to smell they are used less in the rotation until they are phased out.” The caps are of varying material, lighter cotton ones for the warmer months, and wool ones for colder weather, but always the same style. The patterns vary as well, mainly plaid patterns although some are solid. Roberts will often take the time to modify the size if necessary by carefully stitching a fold in the back so that they fit him just right.

Dijana Savic, who lives and works in Paris, collects crochet pieces, a collection that she inherited from her mom and aunts. Her grandmother crocheted the tops and dresses that were eventually passed down to Dijana and her sister. This inherited collection led her to seek out more crocheted pieces, and she says, “there is something so elegant and enchanting about these handmade pieces and details.” When it comes to caring for these items, Dijana is very attentive. “There are certain pieces that are more resistant and durable and, therefore, I do wear them more often.  However, the crochet dress is a rarity—it's for particular occasions.” Even with the crochet tops, which she wears more regularly, Dijana likens wearing them to a “ceremonious occasion.” This is, perhaps, due to the nostalgic effect that these pieces play, as her mother once wore them.

This personal lineage remind me of another great section from Women in Clothes, “Mothers as Other.” In this section, women were asked to send photographs of their mothers from the time before they had children and describe what they saw. Author, Sheila Heti said this of her mother’s photo, “That dress is great. I’m always looking for dresses like that. I move like my mother and have her body—especially her feet and hands. It troubled me when I noticed it as a girl, but now it makes me feel warm and closer to her.” I have felt this many times looking at pictures of my own mother before she was a mother, and wishing she had saved this dress, those jeans, or that scarf. Dijana’s collection also reminds us of the potential depth of clothing, when it is not viewed simply as a superficial form of mindless consumption

And finally, back to my own collection of striped shirts in varying colors and sleeve-lengths. I’ve been collecting them since 2008, and initially, they were only long-sleeved striped shirts due to Chicago weather, but recently I’ve acquired a few with short-sleeves. A strict requirement for them is that they are made from 100% cotton. Colors and stripe thickness can vary.

I think I seek this item out because I’ve watched too many Godard films and have been influenced by the fashions in them. But honestly, I enjoy prints in clothing, and stripes are an easy one to mix with other prints, like flowers. I do take special care to preserve these items. One Sonia Rykiel striped top that was perhaps one of the first in this collection, I have patched the hole in the elbow so that I can continue to wear it. I try to rotate them so that the old ones can live longer while the younger ones get more usage.

But in the end, they are clothes and will fall apart and that is one thing that I value more than any collection—the ability to say goodbye to an item and move on. My mother didn’t save the dresses and jeans that I drool over in photos from her youth. She didn’t bother packing all her clothes or mine each time that we moved. Instead, she taught me how to value my clothes while at the same time understand what was no longer necessary. It’s these skills of selection and necessity that have helped me navigate through the sea of striped shirts and pick just one or ignore them all until the one I really want sails along or goes on sale, whichever comes first.

fields.Name: A Case for Slow Fashion: Considering fibers
fields.HTML:
A Case for Slow Fashion: Considering fibers

by Ana Sekler

Reading labels on food items, personal toiletries, and pet food is something most 21st century individuals have grown accustomed to doing, whether we read them in order to know how many calories are in those pretzels or to know what our beloved pets are eating. While many are concerned with what they put into their bodies, few care about what covers the body in the form of clothing.

I was taught to read clothing labels by my mother. She never gave me explicit reasoning, but I figured it out through all our time spent researching also known as shopping. She would gauge the fabric against the price and decide accordingly, so $5 was not too much to pay for a pair of 100% cotton socks but it was too much for 100% polyester socks. Cotton, wool, and linen always took precedence over polyester, viscose, rayon, and acrylic.

As a teenager I had a hard time understanding the difference between acrylic and wool. So many sweaters I would pick up would be made from acrylic and it appeared just as soft as wool, but my mother was always wary, suggesting I wait until I find one made from merino wool. You never know until you try, and the same goes with fabrics. The acrylic sweaters I owned never lasted as long as the wool ones, and often pilled so I would spend half my dressing time removing the pilled fabric.

After other unsuccessful attempts with synthetic fibers—the polyester dresses and blouses that were so sweet on the outside yet so stinky on the inside: making me sweat and feel like I was wearing a plastic rain poncho—I gave up on synthetics for the most part. I became a devotee to natural fibers, mainly cotton, as it was the most prevalent and affordable. My friend Emily, a fellow cotton lover, would joke each time she saw me, saying, “What are you wearing? Is it cotton?” And we would laugh as, nine times out of ten, it was indeed cotton.

Reading Kate Fletcher’s book, Sustainable Fashion and Textiles: Design Journeys (2014), I was surprised to learn about the environmental toll waged by natural fibers. The large quantities of water used and pesticides applied to cotton are strongly correlated with negative environmental impacts, like according to Fletcher, reduced soil fertility, loss of biodiversity, water pollution and severe health problems. While irrigated cotton may require more water than polyester and other synthetics, these synthetics in turn require more energy.

It seemed like a no-win situation, energy and water both being quickly depleted for the production of fibers. Such a large issue cannot be tackled in one fell swoop, so this is the first in a series of cases for Slow Fashion where I will outline various regions of the fashion industry, from production to consumption, in order to gain a better understanding in making personal choices regarding the purchase of garments.

The first thing to consider in the chain is production, and by that I mean the fiber itself as that will affect and be affected by the rest of the cycle. For me, it seems like a logical starting point. According to Fletcher’s statistics, the two fibers dominating the market are cotton (25.10%), and polyester (36.46%). Overall, manufactured fibers, like polyester, nylon, and acrylic, and are on top. But there is no easy answer here. Although natural fibers are generally better for the environment, that does not mean they should be the only ones to cultivate. It is a mixture of the two, as synthetic and natural fibers have positive and negative sides.

Fletcher proposes a diversification of material in order to achieve a level of harmony. “This strategy of materials diversity involves replacing some of the dominant or high-impact fibres with alternatives including low-chemical and organic cotton, hemp, lyocell, wool and PLA,” says Fletcher. Lyocell is a cellulosic fiber made from wood pulp. It was developed in the 1980s and is claimed to be environmentally responsible, although it is an energy-intensive fiber. Lyocell is becoming much more common and is a great summertime fabric. I have one sleeveless top from Lyocell and it is one of the lightest and breeziest summer tops in my wardrobe. Polylactic acid (PLA) is unlike conventional synthetics in that it is made from renewable sources, presently corn, and is compostable, unlike polyester, which is made from fossil fuels and non-biodegradable. PLA however like other biopolymers still retains negative effects of intensive agricultural methods required to produce corn.

These alternatives generally yield a low energy and low water usage percentage as compared to conventionally grown cotton or synthetics like acrylic and viscose. Reading garment labels before purchase not only yields benefits to your skin, it also helps the environment. I have never believed it possible to change the world, only to change my actions, and what I can control, which is in itself a difficult task.

While I am not keen on moralizing about fashion, I am interested in considering the material aspects that make up our world and our human relation to the physical world. How much of these problems are the production? How much are the consumption? Fletcher, in her other book Fashion & Sustainability: Design for Change (2011) presents a lovely map titled “Sustainabilica: A new continent of fibres”, where she outlines the various fibers we should be incorporating and how much space each should take, as if they were each their own country. Organic, low-chemical, low-water and rain-fed cotton takes up the largest space, with recycled and recyclable nylon, and polyester occupying a fair amount as well. While I have only touched upon the first chapter of Fletcher’s research from Sustainable Fashion and Textiles here, future cases for slowing down fashion will continue to appear in Chic Shifter. If we simply make a concerted effort to slow ourselves down by reading the label and considering the fabric, then that action will, in turn, dictate the supply.

fields.Name: Exploring What Fashion Isn't
fields.HTML:
Exploring What Fashion Isn’t

by Shi An

In fashion, we have things that are, and things that are not. When considering our options, rarely do we consider the options that are not available. This consideration can be depressing because we might realize we cannot afford that option, or that our body does not fit that option. But understanding why we do not or cannot wear something helps us understand our own meaningful positioning within society.

For example, I choose not to wear a dress in public, because I choose not to present as female. I do consider my personality to hold many traditionally understood elements of femininity, (my name literally translates to “woman under a roof”), yet my inability to wear something overtly feminine indicates my chosen positioning in society as male. My fashion non-choice to wear a dress illuminates my positioning within gender presenting more so than my personality or self concept. In this article, I will focus myopically upon what people do not wear, in hopes of uncovering some deep truths and useful applications.

Sans-culottes: Wearing Your Without

An important manifestation is in the way people have used clothing to celebrate their own lacking in order to create authentic, renewed agency for themselves. For the sans-culottes of France, these working class people defined themselves and their movement through the lack of a particular garment that signified class wealth, the culotte (knee breeches). The sans-culottes managed to find style and pride through a conventionally shamed lacking. The inability to afford culottes led the sans-culottes to a communal choice to not wear them, transforming what they could not wear into what they did not wear, challenging the assumption that one did not wear a culotte simply because one couldn’t afford it. As we wear any type of clothing, we must recognize what we do not wear as well, and how we can gain agency and communal recognition through it.

Black Panther Party, disobbedienti: Confronting the Absence of Color

...the world is revealed as haunted by absences to be realized, and each this appears with a cortege of absences which point to it and determine it. –Jean-Paul Sartre, Being and Nothingness 1.

Fashion too can be understood through its “cortege of absences.” The Black Panther Party in the United States, through an all black uniform that includes black shoes, black slacks, black leather jackets, black berets, and black sunglasses, (and black guns as an accessory), showed how fashion can haunt through an absence: in this case, the absence of color. The absence of color in their clothing haunts those who wear color and acts as a reminder to all that there is a fundamental absence of Black people in systems of institutional power.

On the other end of the white-black spectrum are the disobbedienti of the 1990’s Italian anti-globalization movement. The disobbedienti called themselves tute bianche (white overalls), wearing their namesakes, along with white shoes, white hoods, white masks and white shields, equipped to combat violent interactions with police. The ghostly, all-white outfit could appear as a challenge to adherents of high fashion culture and the industry’s ties to global capitalism, the very power structure the disobbedienti speak out against. Using fashion to embody a “cortege of absences,” the Italian disobbedienti  and the Black Panther Party each found an extreme of colorlessness to embody themselves and their message. Each outfit (dis)engaged similarly with color, yet manifested as polar opposites, in terms of color.

Sky Cubacub and Radical Visibility: Color as Immoderate Presence

Similar to haunting with absence of color (disobbedienti, Black Panther Party), there is also a way to send a message through the exceptionally abundant presence of color. Chicago-based fashion designer Sky Cubacub uses a tactic they call “radical visibility.” Aligning the fashion line with queer and crip communities, Cubacub explains the position, “I am using radical visibility as a call to action to dress in order to not be ignored, to reject ‘passing’ and assimilation.” 2. Cubacub refers to their personal fashion aesthetic through a comparison to a unique type of animal in its relation to color and presence:  “All my clothing is supposed to be […] kind of inviting but also saying, ‘I’m bold enough to be wearing this, so you can stay away.’ Like brightly colored, poisonous frogs or beetles.” 3 Seen alongside the disobbedienti and the Black Panther Party who expressed and defined themselves through not-color, radical visibility expresses itself through not not-color—that is to say, Cubacub’s deviance from normative use of color-in-moderation is similar to the deviation from color itself by the Black Panthers and the disobbedienti.

Nakedness: Non-being of Clothing Itself

[...]the fear of being surprised in a state of nakedness [is] only a symbolic specification of original shame; the body symbolizes here our defenseless state as objects. […] This is why the Biblical symbol of the fall after the original sin is the fact that Adam and Eve “know that they are naked.” –Jean-Paul Sartre, Being and Nothingness4

Arguably the most fundamental representation of negation in fashion is the lack of all clothes: nakedness. And this nakedness is historically read as a source of shame in western culture. On April 6th, 1968, Bobby Hutton became the very first Black Panther member to be shot dead by the police, due in part to his shame for nakedness. As Kathleen Cleaver recounts, “A tear gas canister blew up, and the basement they were hiding in caught on fire. They decided they didn’t want to burn to death, they would rather surrender. Eldridge told Bobby Hutton to take off all your clothes, so they can’t say you’re concealing a weapon. When you surrender, take off everything. But Bobby was embarrassed and he just took off his shirt, and he kept on his pants.”5 Hutton, only 17, and still carrying adolescent embarrassments, failed to take off all of his clothes when stepping out of the basement to surrender. Bobby Hutton did not subvert Eldridge’s order to take off all of his clothes; rather, he fell victim to the original shame of Adam and Eve. Most of our fashion choices do not lead to life or death situations, as was the case for Bobby Hutton. But there is something to learn from his decision that day. All fashion is built outward from nakedness, and if we don't recognize our basic canvas as beautiful and valid, we fall victim to the bodily shame imposed upon us by culture, and the act of wearing clothes becomes a desperate concealment of our bodies, rather than its flattering complement. Benefits of Seeing What is Not There

I have discussed some powerful iterations of what is not in fashion: to not wear a culotte, to not wear color, to not not wear color, and to not wear clothes at all. But this negative lens I have donned for this article is not necessarily how the real world application of fashion works: we do not make fashion decisions based on what our decisions are not. Yes, we may weigh some alternative choices, but we do not dress ourselves consciously informed by “that indissoluble dyad, being and nothingness” between being and nothingness that Sartre speaks of. 6 Generally, we make clothing choices based on what the clothing is: that is, what it does, how it looks, how it feels. These are more important than the cerebral concepts Sartre explores in Being and Nothingness. But, just as silence naturally contributes to music, just as negative space on a canvas helps contribute to a drawing or painting, what something is not helps inform our fashion sense. Our lacking of certain articles of clothing inform what we do wear for balance, strict grayscale helps inform our use of color, and the shape, size and hue of our naked bodies help inform our wearing of clothes completely. Using Sartre’s initial inspiration, we can focus on what we don’t have and what we don’t wear as much as what we do, in order to expand our intellectual perspective on how we express ourselves individually and communally through fashion.

fields.Name: Georg Simmel and the Passion for Fashion
fields.HTML:
Georg Simmel and the Passion for Fashion

by Ana Nezna

Fashion is not a passion; it is, however, passing. One of the fundamental elements of its survival is its transitory nature, the speed at which it aims to trick and lure us unaware into its web of consumption. Things are changing though. More and more today, consumers are growing aware that their actions have consequences: on the planet, on other humans, and on themselves.

The concept of Slow Fashion came into being thanks to the Slow Food movement, which began in Italy about twenty years ago. Slow Food began as a response to fast food, advocating a return to the joy of cooking and eating, to reconnecting people to one another, to their communities, and to the larger world. Slow Fashion began in much the same way, around twelve years ago as a response to the grave problems facing the garment industry. Factory disasters, like the Rana Plaza collapse in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in 2013 that killed a reported 1,129 workers, and the growing exploitation of natural resources have made some designers rethink their practices. Elizabeth L. Cline does a thorough job of describing many of these abuses as well as solutions in her book, Overdressed (2012). I will address one of the solutions she suggests: the strength of the consumer’s choice.

Over a century ago in 1901, Georg Simmel, the German sociologist, wrote an essay, titled “Fashion.” While the language denoting a primitive society needs to be adjusted for today’s intellectual context, the work still resonates in 2016 and can be linked to ideals set forth in the Slow Fashion movement.

“Fashion is the imitation of a given example and satisfies the demand for social adaptation; it leads the individual upon the road which all travel, it furnishes a general condition, which resolves the conduct of every individual into a mere example. At the same time it satisfies in no less degree the need of differentiation, the tendency towards dissimilarity, the desire for change and contrast, on the one hand by a constant change of contents, which gives to the fashion of today an individual stamp as opposed to that of yesterday and of tomorrow, on the other hand because fashions differ for different classes—the fashions of the upper stratum of society are never identical with those of the lower; in fact, they are abandoned by the former as soon as the latter prepares to appropriate them. Thus fashion represents nothing more than one of the many form of life by the aid of which we seek to combine in uniform spheres of activity the tendency towards social equalization with the desire for individual differentiation and change.”

There is the crux of Simmel’s argument; fashion creates uniformity and individualization at once. From there begins the challenge of the contemporary consumer of clothing as an aspect of fashion. The excerpt contains a hefty amount of information, all aspects of I may not be able to address, so let’s start slowly.

Simmel’s idea is that fashion gives a particular crest to its age, to differentiate it from yesterday and tomorrow, kind of like the gold colored seals found on men’s navy-colored blazers. What happens in much of mainstream fashion is a perpetual yesterday, with some future occasionally tossed in. This endless search for trend is what is in fact destroying the fashionistae (the plural of fashionista), I propose. On this madcap route to trend, quality and endurance have been forgotten.

The dignity of a garment lies not in its novelty but in its fortitude. The fast fashion giants—H&M, Zara, Forever 21, Uniqlo, The Gap—have a hold on buy three, get one free. Who needs four of the same t-shirt, shirt, or skirt? Apparently, all of us do. I have plenty of similar garments, primarily in the tops realm; they’re all cotton in either long or short sleeves. However, there are several that stand out, from memory: a brown-and-black striped cotton top from Sonia Rykiel the elbow of which I’ve patched once; a blue –and-white thin-striped cotton top with a by-now stretched out neck that adds a nice amount of allure; from the ‘label fell off because it’s so old’, and a pink, button-down shirt with little red mice chasing dispersed pieces of cheese all over it from Anthropologie. I’ve had these three tops for varying lengths of time, but all from seven to ten years old, and I think they will last another seven to ten years, primarily because I care for them and mend them. I can record all three from memory, not from digital memories, but of the ones that actually use the space in my brain, so they are special to me.

The second idea of Simmel’s that I’d like to address is the one about class differences in fashion—how the upper echelon differentiates from the the lower class, and in addition that fashions are abandoned by the upper strata if they become appropriated by the lower. It is, at first glance, quite easily true and a myriad of examples can be given to prove the point. However I find it much more stimulating to think of the appropriation of the lower class’ fashion by the upper class. Styles come from the street and they always have.

Walking on the street creates fashion. Why is sportswear so popular now? No surprise, regular folks have been wearing sportswear stylishly for decades. Binaries of class aren’t necessary. The simple acknowledgement that the upper and lower strata tale, borrow, and, sometimes, steal from one another is cyclical. It is interesting to note that designers like Vetements are profiting on the working-class culture, offering DHL t-shirts for $330. (Henry Ford increased the worker’s salary so that they could afford to buy a Ford automobile. I wonder if the same is true of Vetements garment makers?) I am simply remarking upon mediocrity of the design. The word vêtements in French means clothes. It is a cheeky name for a clothing label, but does it have more than cheek? Is there a functioning brain atop the cheeks, I wonder?

Fashion, according to Simmel is fickle in the sense that while it promotes an attachment to a larger group, it also encourages individual differentiation. Even in striving to be an individual though we echo the sentiment to those that desire to be alike. This is fascinating to think about, because I know that it is relevant of some of my clothing choices. I also strongly desire to belong and be separate.

Four to five winters ago, I would regularly pass a woman on my morning commute with a rich, wine-colored fall/early winter coat, covered in a large hood. I loved seeing not only the woman, but also her coat. A winter or so later, I found a wine colored hooded wool coat, different from hers in its details, length and fit, but nonetheless, inspired by this woman who I would see walking. In my desire to differentiate myself, I had become a part of this woman.

More recently, the same has happened with a fall/spring navy trench coat. My initial inspiration for the absolute need for such a coat lay in the British detective mini-series, River, with the actor Stellan Skarsgård, whom I know from Lars Von Trier films. In this series, Skarsgård wears the perfect detective coat; it’s knee-length, waterproof, and black. Mine, however, is navy, and I wear it all the time since the weather has been significantly above freezing. Recently, I remembered another passerby who inspired this coat. Like the woman who inspired the red coat, this man has worn his navy coat in every passing memory I have of him, and I realize that in some little ways, fashion allows me to emulate people that intrigue me.

We each have our stories with the world that surrounds us, from our furniture to our pets and loved ones. Clothing is a part of that belonging and opposing, which makes it important to consider. Regardless of economic niveau, the thoughtful choice is part of everyone’s daily routine.

fields.Name: Autumn
fields.HTML: Week two was easy breezy, since I have a lot of neutral clothing. However, I do not have neutral accessories. I usually wear black with a pop of color in accessories but not this week. There are a few items I want to buy for myself after wearing mostly black and a day of beige/brown such as a white collared shirt and some black pants. Again, this limit made me want to go shopping.

fields.Name: Jess
fields.HTML:
Since the majority of my wardrobe is cotton, wool, and linen, it wasn’t overly challenging for me to adhere to the limits of Fabric Shifter. What was more challenging — and rewarding — was simply being acutely aware of what I was wearing and noticing how my personal style has changed over the past year since graduating from art school.

When I started working as a writer in the tech industry, I began to notice that women in that world often seem to have only one of two choices deemed “professional”: Ann Taylor LOFT office wear or hoodies with jeans. I refuse to adhere to either of those, and instead wear biker boots and oversized silhouettes to work (to the applause of my co-workers). And I still stick by my personal rule: I refuse to work anywhere that won’t allow me to wear a miniskirt on the job.

fields.Name: Ana
fields.HTML: Initially I was afraid of approaching this week, mainly because I don’t have many colorful bottoms. By the third day when I wore yellow, I began to realize the effects that color was having on my mood in a positive manner, so this was my favorite week.

fields.Name: Constance
fields.HTML:
It was a challenge for me to incorporate different pieces from my summer wardrobe that could transition into fall looks. With the weather constantly changing, my thoughts on what to wear also changed, I would layer skirts with sweaters, dresses with light jackets and leggings.

Days 1 and 2 worked great for biking downtown, I received loads of compliments on my white sneakers. Day 3 was especially exciting for me because I got to wear a couple of new items I picked up while in Greece, a sleeveless dress layered with a cropped sweater and a cape. By the time I reached day 5, I felt I had exhausted the skirt/ sweater look and was finding it hard to create an ensemble that fit the criteria as well as meet my functionality needs.

Overall the limit made me very happy that I could still enjoy pieces that I may not have put together otherwise. Is it worth it, let me work it!​

fields.Name: Shari
fields.HTML: I like dressing in all neutrals when the color combos are interesting; like wearing brown with gray. I feel pretty lame if I end up in all black and white (which I did on two days). I have a personal rule to never wear a black top with gray pants... I can't think of anything less inspiring.

fields.Name: Ela
fields.HTML:
Participating in this experiment was a lot of fun. In this combining seasons experiment, I used few layers but also wanted something that reminded of summer.

In this experiment I usually wore few layers but always had something summery like tops or skirts. I don’t like skirts a lot but I love tops and pants.

I often combined my tops with pants. When I felt happy I wore my giraffe top with my black pants and white shoes with giraffe earrings. If I needed to feel more energy I wore my black top with my orange sweater. In my opinion, orange always gives out a more energetic preference. My alternative was a sweater with bright colored stripes.

Even when it was a drowsy or rainy day, I wore my colorful flowers rain boots and orange sweater to feel more energized. That happened once when I dressed up in a cute black skirt with one of my favorite tops. The top has a camera printed on it,which reminds me of summer time.Whenever I wanted to feel comfy, I wore my black top with a gray sweater…voilà ready to go.

fields.Name: Ela
fields.HTML:
Participating in this experiment was a lot of fun for me. I love jewelry and silver jewelry is my favorite. In my collection there is taqua jewelry, pink pearls, wood and fiber jewelry and a bunch of different types of minerals framed in silver.

It was a lot of fun for me to participate in this experiment. First I chose the jewelry and then I tried to combine my outfit with it. For example, I picked my giraffe earrings and matched them with my giraffe t-shirt, black pants and white shoes.

I also like red a lot so I picked my red wooden earrings and wood hand-painted bracelet with my favorite red top, black pants, and white shoes. I chose to wear my favorite taqua orange earrings and the same kind of bracelet with my orange sweater. When I wanted to be more visible, I picked my big silver earrings, my nice silver leather bracelet, and a really unique silver ring designed by my friend. But when I wanted to be shy, I picked my orange necklaces, which I used as a bracelet and my big silver circle earrings (they match with everything). In addition, I wore a simple t-shirt, jeans, and blue sport sneakers with an orange bird on them.

fields.Name: Ana
fields.HTML: I never consider silhouette in an outfit, often times I wear the same pants/silhouette several times in one week. I found this limit to be somewhat challenging in that I was forced to consider shifting shape above all else.

fields.Name: Jelena
fields.HTML: As I normally wear a base of neutrals with a pop of color, this week was a bit difficult. Masochist that I am, I kept it to no more than two colors to an outfit as well. As I prefer costume jewelry and colorful scarves, I opted out of accessorizing much. I found sticking to a neutral palette kind of a downer though and felt a bit like I was missing something. I guess color in my clothing is really important because I dress pretty simply, especially for an office job.

fields.Name: Autumn
fields.HTML: This week was tough; I actually had to visit my local Good Will to try out some fibers other than cotton! I ended up wearing cotton frequently; it is the fabric of our lives after all. I did find wool easy to wear and occasionally silk. Perhaps my clothing budget influence what fibers I purchase? I’m sure if I had a larger clothing budget I could buy more natural fibers. I was happy when this week was over and was overwhelmed with selfies. At first the selfies were fun then I got burnt out after four weeks of them!

fields.Name: Ana
fields.HTML:
Initially I thought this limit would be easy since I love layering. But it proved to be difficult to mix in summer clothes while still retaining a cohesive look.

Most often for this limit, I resorted to a trusted look that I've been wearing since the age of four: dresses over jeans. I also layered tank tops or t-shirts over sweaters or turtlenecks, which was new for me as a layering technique. I enjoyed it because it allowed me to make new combinations with sweaters that I was starting to grow bored of. Since the limit was in October and the weather was fairly warm, these combinations were not difficult. I hope to remember these techniques when the doldrums of winter hit in January and February. Mixing seasons like this is a potential technique for dealing with seasonal affective disorder. Sartorial limits can do wonders for the psyche.

fields.Name: Shari
fields.HTML: For me, fabrics are a very situational and environmental choice. Luckily, I was in the desert for three days so I wore mostly cotton. If I had gone to work I imagine I would've pulled out a couple of silk shirts and my favorite wool pants. My day one outfit would've also worked well in the neutral or silhouette line-up!

fields.Name: Shari
fields.HTML: On the first day I just wore a patterned dress, so I didn't have to think about putting colors together. The other four days I wore top/bottom combinations that I had never put together before. In that way, this limit felt like an expansion. I think it's easy for me to wear one color and one neutral. I like how weeks two and three pushed me out of that mentality.

fields.Name: Ana
fields.HTML: This limit was fairly easy for me, which is likely due to the fact that I don’t buy many synthetic fibers. But there was a concern one day as a sweater was not entirely made from merino and jeans often add polyester for stretch. I managed to be above the 70% limit every day except for the one where I was exactly at 70% natural fibers.

fields.Name: Ela
fields.HTML:
Participating in this experiment was a lot of fun. I started at week three because I love colors! I think our streets are not colorful enough. The dominant colors in Chicago are classic black and white or shades of gray. I also like black, but every time I wear black I try to compose my outfit with contrast colors such as red, orange, purple, or pink. I have a large collection of colorful clothes that I didn’t have a chance to demonstrate in this week’s project, maybe in the future.

My best friends are purple, orange, red, silver, and pink. I avoid wearing yellow and white, not because I don’t like them, but I just don’t look good in those colors. There is also no green in my color collection. Again, not because I don’t like the color green, it is just not my favorite color. I always try to wear colors that match and come together to create contrast. I absolutely love shoes and jackets. Cute outfits underlined by awesome shoes definitely get people’s attention. Prince no doubt had the best jackets; a nice jacket can make any outfit interesting. I enjoyed this fashion experiment so much. It led me to figure out how much I like stripes, something I hadn’t noticed before.

fields.Name: Ela
fields.HTML: This week was a big challenge, only natural fibers, materials, wool, and leather. In our contemporary world synthetics dominate and I am not a fan. They are mostly not breathable, and make you sweaty and itchy. I always try to buy clothes made from natural fibers. I like silk, and linen because they are breathable, soft and comfy. They are great in the summer. I can’t imagine life without cotton. It is great in the summer and great in the winter. I love wool for its warmth. As accessories, I like the best silver jewelry. In my collection there are pink pearls, wood and fiber jewelry and a bunch of different types of minerals framed in silver. I enjoyed this week a lot, and I started thinking more about fibers and materials in my wardrobe.

fields.Name: Autumn
fields.HTML: I thought this limit was going to be very difficult. Once I began planning my outfits each day it got easier. It was inspiring to see that I could pull off more looks than I thought. The further the week went by made me want to get more adventurous with my outfits. Throughout this week I found myself wanting to go shopping to buy different styles of pants. I realized at the end of this week that perhaps my relationship with clothes has become lazy and I should shop more open-mindedly.

fields.Name: Shari
fields.HTML: I liked looking at my wardrobe this way. I would call this assignment conscious variety rather than limiting. I pulled out a couple of pieces that I don't wear very often, but ultimately all of the complete outfits were combinations that I had worn in the past. I realized that I have a lot of v-necks.

fields.Name: Constance
fields.HTML:
My overall experience of this limit was great, I enjoyed changing my silhouette daily and for the most part I was able to wear my looks from day to night. For the first day I went with an oversized turtleneck and I paired it with my favorite black skinny jeans. Day two I went for my mesh bodysuit with wide leg pants and a kimono-like sweater.

I wanted to keep everything monochromatic but I added a pop of color with my electric blue suede boots.  On the third day I went with a dress that has embroidery and beading along the sleeves and ties at the waist creating an a-line look. By day four I was ready to wear my go to look, which is my long sleeve lace crop with a high waisted skirt. I like wearing this belt my sister bought me with this outfit.  The last day I chose a black fitted turtleneck and a black skirt with high top sneakers. Since I wear black every day, I like to polish my nails with a fun color and I always wear pink lipstick! I felt chic and comfortable every day.

fields.Name: Ana
fields.HTML:
I rarely consider jewelry in choosing an outfit. I tend to go through certain staples for months on end until I choose another staple set of jewelry. Lately I have been wearing gold so my go to has been hoop earrings, gold watch and a couple trusty rings.

This limit was by far the most interesting and difficult limit I have ever done. Simply training myself to think about jewelry first was weird and then choosing an outfit that would allow the focus to be on the jewelry was tough.

I enjoyed this limit immensely and realized that part of the reason I do not vary my jewelry is because it wasn't clearly displayed, something I immediately changed after the limit was over. Although I quickly fell back into my lazy jewelry method, this limit made me realize what I was missing and how much I love these metal or fabric adornments.

fields.Name: Jelena
fields.HTML: Ahhhh, color! Especially coming off of a week without it, I really appreciated being able to play. In contrast to last week, I found that I wear so many bold colors that accessorizing is less important, so I kept that as a theme. My mood got a boost and I found a bit more confidence in my walk. Even my customer meetings went a bit better. I wear jeans most of the week so it was nice to get back to my comfort zone. I find that I treat navy as a neutral color. The jeans and navy top with the red cardigan is indicative of my normal wear. Comfortable and cute is my goal for fashion, but now I'll add color to that list.

fields.Name: Autumn
fields.HTML: Color week was not a stretch for me, I love color! However, I usually only do color on top and denim on the bottom. This was a challenge because I only have blue jeans to wear, thank goodness denim counted as a color! It was fun seeing what others wore via Instagram and Facebook and gave me ideas to snazz up my color game. I loved color week, it was super.

fields.Name: Ana
fields.HTML: While I regularly wear plenty of neutral colors, I still found this shifter to be interesting as I don’t normally wear a week straight with no color or mix of color. As the tops and bottoms had to be neutral, I broke out a gray wool skirt that I haven’t worn in over a year, it was a nice surprise.

fields.HTML:
by Ana Sekler

Where do young fashion designers in Chicago go after they’ve received their degrees? Many leave the city for brighter prospects on one of the coasts or in Europe. Those that choose to stay and are lucky enough, go to Macy’s. To the eleventh floor that is, where the Chicago Fashion Incubator (CFI), a two-year fashion residency program for emerging designers, resides.

Although this may come as a surprise to some, Chicago has a history of garment manufacturing, which flourished primarily during and slightly after World War II. The city is still home to high-quality men’s suit makers: Hart Schaffner Marx and Oxxford Clothes. That history was somehow forgotten, until former Mayor Daley began the city’s fashion initiative in 2005. CFI and Fashion Focus Chicago were two of the products of this endeavor. While Fashion Focus, a week of fashion shows and talks about the fashion industry has been sadly defunct since 2015, the CFI still appears to be going strong.

“When Mayor Daley started the incubator back in 2007, he had hoped to bring up more manufacturing, make it alive again, make it a center, providing more jobs for people and making it a potential place for designers to stay longer here or to really create their businesses,” says Andrea Reynders, Design Director of CFI. Reynders who is also Professor Emeritus at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC), where she earned her BFA, began working on the board of the Chicago Fashion Incubator when former student, Lara Miller, then executive director of CFI, asked her to join in 2010. When Miller left to focus on her own clothing line, Reynders took over as Design Director and mentor in 2014. The board also hired Trideep Das, a brand strategist, as business director at that time.

The incubator provides six fledgling designers with the resources to bridge the gap from fashion students to fashion entrepreneurs. CFI supports the designers by offering them a workspace, shared offices, and a curriculum of business and creative workshops, and mentoring. “Coming from a strong art and design background, there was virtually no business knowledge, so understanding my consumer, how to do a competitor’s grid, understanding the ins and outs of that, I’m learning all that,” says Shruti Kirti, who is now in her second year at the incubator. Like Kirti, Anna Brown, another CFI second-year designer, agrees that the incubator has helped her to professionalize her practice while offering crucial creative and business support.

The designers have varied focuses: four in womenswear, one in menswear, and one in swimwear. Each develops two collections during their time at the incubator. Kirti, who was a student of Reynder’s at SAIC, began the program in March 2015, and was working on her fall/winter 2016 collection when I first met with her in November. Her clothing line concentrates on career wear with functionality. “Your clothes really have to carry you through the day, so I’m working with a specific fabric that’s referred to as scuba,” says Kirti. “It doesn’t wrinkle or stretch easily, but is comfortable and soft, and it adds a little funkiness to career wear.”

Their collections are as varied as their goals at CFI. Whereas Kirti is focused on selling her collection direct to consumer, Brown is moving towards selling her collection to boutiques. “Coming here, my goal was to move into selling wholesale to boutiques as I was having trouble reaching my customer. I wasn’t able to market myself properly, so I thought to give the wholesale route a shot,” says Brown.

Brown makes clothing for someone who is looking for more creativity in her wardrobe. “I try to make a more nuanced modern collection. I’m sort of a minimalist and I guess a little bit of a modernist in terms of my approach to design, as I try only to include what is essential in terms of structure to the garment,” she says. Brown is interested in creating contemporary staples for a women’s wardrobe, clothes that retain an ease of use, but that also define the body, and have structural interest and functional yet refreshing details like pockets.

Midwestern cities like Chicago often have a hard time keeping their designers, not due to the lack of creative energy but to the lack of manufacturing. “The lack of manufacturing here is a problem for all of us; it makes it difficult,” says Brown. Recalling the early strength of the Apparel Industry Board of Illinois (AIBI) in the 1970s, Reynders says: “That organization was very powerful at some point, and they even built what was the garment center, right next door to the Merchandise Mart. Their dream was to bring buyers to Chicago, and it worked for a couple of years, because people were curious and interested. The point was to build up Chicago, but it was a big struggle, and I believe primarily due to the manufacturing; couldn’t start the fire under it, it would always smolder out.”

Today, with organizations like CFI, Chicago is working not only to educate but also to retain its local designers, like Kirti, who says, “I want to grow this business here and use local resources. Midwestern is a compliment to me, that’s what I want it to be.” So far, Kirti has been successful. Her fabric is sourced locally, and she has been able to locate a seamstress and photographer in Chicago with the help of the incubator resources.

Being outside of a centralized fashion capital has advantages for emerging designers. “The Chicago market isn’t over-saturated and we get to experiment and explore who we are as designers,” says Kirti. CFI supports its designers in various ways, with one-on-one mentoring, trunk shows, and practical business advice. “I tend to think of the Midwest as meat and potatoes, it’s serious about its work, we’re not flamboyant,” says Reynders. The incubator designers are always at work, whether cutting fabric for their patterns, organizing photo shoots, or traveling to boutiques to show their current collections. “I’ve taken everything up a level here, and I wouldn’t be able to do this on my own,” says Brown of her time at CFI.

The life of a CFI fashion designer isn’t only about dress forms, fabric, and designs; a lot of footwork is involved. “Many of the designers get on the road; either they pack and fly to a city, make appointments with boutique owners, show their collections, and sometimes there’s a trunk show involved,” explains Reynders. When I met with Anna Brown in February, she had just returned from a short trip to New York, scouting boutiques that may be potential buyers for her collection, and was busy starting on her spring/summer 2017 collection.

“I really think there’s something amazing that’s going to happen in fashion,” says Reynders. “There’s going to be a huge change and I feel it already. There are many small, independent designers in New York, California, Chicago, St. Louis who are making a really good product, trying to make it locally, or at least nationally.”

Bridget Foley’s article “Fashion’s Existential Crisis” published October 2015, in Women’s Wear Daily, echoes Reynder’s sentiment. “It feels as if fashion is on one giant collision course with itself and everyone’s talking about it, designers included. While no one wants to turn back the clock (not possible, and reactionary doesn’t fly in fashion), many wonder—out loud—how to evolve (or perhaps revolutionize) the system in a way that makes sense.”

The responsibility for conscious fashion is not solely left to the designer but, perhaps, and even more so, to the consumer. Shruti Kirti laughs as she relates that she herself does not shop much, and advises the fast-fashion, trend-hungry consumer, to simply “shop less!” This may be the key formula to creating a healthier relationship to fashion: shop less and analyze more in order to develop personal style, while hopefully supporting our local clothes makers.

fields.HTML:
by Ana Sekler

“I am not a fashion designer, I am a clothing designer and I see a huge distinction in that,” says Leigh DeLeonardo, answering my initial question about her work as a fashion designer. I had been using the two words fairly interchangeably, and I was intrigued by her response as it forced me to consider my usage which had become automatic, and in many ways, empty of meaning. According to DeLeonardo, fashion is transitory, always chasing a trend, forever searching for the new, and is a heavily loaded word. She prefers to create clothing that is timeless, that builds an environment for the wearer, leaving her the freedom to go about the important aspects of their day, while supporting her in these endeavors.

Clarity and rigor are evident not only in DeLeonardo’s discussion of her design, but also in the execution of her creative process. “I’m a firm believer in having a supportive process. I learned that looking at a gigantic task like getting a collection on the racks is extremely stressful. So I break it down into its stages and its steps, and I let that guide me through to the end,”she says. First, she researches at the Newberry library, leafing through old copies of Vogue or Gazette du Bon Ton; then she sketches, sometimes up to 300 sketches a collection; from there she iterates until she arrives at a garment that is born of her efforts, editing down to around 20 favorite garments.

DeLeonardo creates several collections throughout the year including seasonal transitions, loungewear, separates, and a linen line, with an average of about nine pieces per collection. Since she is in the position of being both a storeowner at Union Handmade, a boutique representing about fifteen different designers, and a clothing designer, DeLeonardo has to wear multiple hats and provide the variety of garments needed for the store. With the help of Jamie LaPorta, her partner at Union and knitwear designer, DeLeonardo develops these mini collections to fill any gaps that may exist in the store’s offerings.

She has used the same woven labels bearing her name since the beginnings of her career, from about 1986. In addition to marking her clothes, the Leigh DeLeonardo label acts as an editor for the designer. “This label tells me what I can do in a way, like if I wanted to make a big fun pair of overalls, I couldn’t do it with that label, it just wouldn’t make sense,” she says. The Camp shirt is one example of the classic and sophisticated aesthetic of the Leigh DeLeonardo label.

DeLeonardo found a way around her internal editor and created a new label, Union brand, that allows her to create more relaxed, youthful, and simple pieces at a lower price point. Along with LaPorta, she developed the Union brand, both to fill a need in the shop, and to challenge herself as a designer.

The Union garments are playful and less refined. A Union bowling shirt, in linen, one of the designer’s favorite fabrics, is full of surprises, offering a small sailor collar and pockets. Pockets are not unique to the Union brand; they are part of much of what the designer creates, believing in the utility as well as quality of an item of clothing. While the majority of DeLeonardo’s garments come in solid colors or yarn dyes, Union offers a dress and skirt in a gray and black plaid with hints of red. Pattern is not limited to the Union label; the spring/summer collection, for example, includes floral print fabrics. Much of the difference between the two labels lies in the detail, and finishing of the garments. Anything made for the Leigh DeLeonardo label takes more time than with Union, according to the designer.

Asking a clothing designer if they choose fabric or decide the shape of the garment first is like the chicken and egg question, one cannot exist without the other, but each designer inevitably has their own method. “My work is about the cut, shape and detail so I need to find fabric that supports these elements.  More recently I've been occasionally starting with the fabric and letting it tell me what to do with it.  I think this is a great way to develop an idea but also it's a bit of a necessity because of how hard it has become to find great fabric.  Sometimes you have to use what you find rather than finding what you need,” she says. The limiting fabric choices are something that all small-scale designers struggle with and the one thing that DeLeonardo misses from her days of wholesaling to stores like Nordstrom and Saks Fifth Avenue. But the greater creative freedom and closer relationship with the customer far outweigh any negatives of working independently.

The day we met, DeLeonardo’s dark, shoulder-length hair lay in two braids, and her thick bangs were welcoming and youthful. She wore a linen top of her own design, black trousers and funky yet comfortable Trippen shoes. Like her shoes, DeLeonardo’s designs exude a feeling of coziness, but not in a lazy way. She is concerned about the quality, the fit, the fabric, her customer; and every little detail is contemplated by this American designer. “I come from the place of being a problem solver,and my designing is very much inspired by the problems that I’m trying to solve,” says DeLeonardo. Including American designers in our closets is something worthy of attention and action.

While my closet is sadly devoid of any garments bearing the Made in USA label, save for a couple American Apparel garments, DeLeonardo reminds me of the gravity of this situation while discussing the Limiting section of Chic Shifter. She suggests a limit of wearing only American-made garments, which I quickly realize would be next to impossible for the majority of Americans. My clothing consumption has been slowly shifting with age and awareness; I choose to buy less on trend and spend more on quality and growth. Both the Union and Leigh DeLeonardo garments seem to me like they could take me through various stages of my future.

fields.Name: Katrin Schnabl
fields.HTML:
by Ana Sekler

Fashion, like dance, belongs to the body. Both are separated from the visual arts. In a 2007 article from Fashion Theory “Fashion as Art; Is Fashion Art?” Sanda Miller posits that, “[W]e even have a category of activities positioned at the interstices of the visual arts, including dance, circus clowns and culture, kitsch, nature, rain, personal beauty, etc., which, like fashion, were not traditionally considered to be art and thus subjects for aesthetics.” While dance has always been considered one of the seven fine arts, this debate continues today with regard to fashion. But designers like Katrin Schnabl, eschews this argument; she is a dancer, fashion designer, artist, and educator.

Beginning as a dancer in her native Frankfurt, Germany, Schnabl made her own costumes. “I thought every dancer made their own costumes, and it was not until I came to New York that it became quite clear to me that no, not every dancer has the same kind of energy about addressing what needs to be on them in order to perform, and what I needed to do to perform,” she told me. Her relationship with the body comes first from dance, from considering how it navigates and engages with space to how it activates that same space. She considers dance the first art. “It doesn’t need language,” she says. “It is very direct; it’s in time and in sync with the body, and it happens here and now.”

Through her work with dance companies and avant-garde theaters in both Frankfurt and the downtown dance scene of New York, she gained much experience that continues to influence her design philosophy today. She worked with a variety of body types, both male and female, and most importantly, learned what elements can be added to a dance, without being distracting, to help the dance read clearer. This particular idea translates into her approach to fashion design. She is interested in taking away from a garment, in allowing the garment to be worn, not to be the one doing the wearing. “To me it’s a lot about what can you take away before it collapses, like the Mikado game of pick-up sticks. The dancer or wearer does so much, I don’t want to compete with or overpower the wearer,” she says.

Speaking about her transition to fashion design, Schnabl recalls: “in an interesting way you generate a lot of ideas and you vet them against choreographic limitations, entrances and exits, from the bodies themselves. You start with a lot and you narrow it down to relatively little. So you have all of this leftover material, it may not have been right for a particular dance, but in and by themselves they were pretty cool, so I would start wearing them.” After taking a self-imposed sabbatical from dancing, Schnabl enrolled in a draping class at the Fashion Institute of Technology, which she enjoyed so much that she ended up continuing on to receive her BFA in 1995.

Schnabl doesn’t speak about her design work in traditional seasonal collections, from autumn/winter or spring/summer, but in more abstract notions, choosing to address the ideas behind the garments, like the importance of fabric. One of her ideas about fabric reminded me of my beginner level sewing class at Vogue Fabrics several summers ago and I wished that someone had told me that when I was choosing a fabric for my pencil skirt. “I’m always saying the hand picks the fabric, keep the eye off of it, because the eye isn’t a good fabric picker, so the hand has to pick. The eye gets to do a lot of other things,” she explains. I, however, picked the fabric with my eye and ended up with an unstable pencil skirt. Schnabl, however, knows her fabrics, “I think it’s a nice luxury that I’ve evolved towards, I don’t want to work with fabrics that don’t feel good. At the end of the day it ends up on the body, and it has to go through my hand, cutting it and sewing it. Why have a fabric that is not satisfying in the process of making?”

Schnabl is attracted to the element of surprise in her work. Fashion is a field that she knows so well but continues to offer nuances of discovery, much like her garments did for me when I saw them in motion. On the day we met, she was wearing garments of her own making—from the soft white jeans, a sleeveless gray top, and a surprising tunic that turned into a shop coat. When she stood up to show me how the tunic functioned, her dancing days were immediately visible. She is a tall, svelte woman whose poised movements are those of a dancer. About the tunic, Schnabl says that she couldn’t make up her mind while draping, so she made it do multiple things. It can be worn the way she initially had it on, more like a vest or tied like a shop coat, or reversed and worn to the front like a dress.

Tiny hints of color are another important consideration in Schnabl’s design aesthetic. “When it comes to color, it’s the first thing you see, it really drives the emotion,” she says. “You pick up the color before you see the shape, definitely before you see the detail and before you get close.” Her use of color has grown to be a brand signifier; people love that little bit of articulation, the attention paid to the garment inside and out. Sometimes the color is subtle, as with her gray tunic, where a strip of orange flashes out from the inside or as another layer to her gray top. This direct use of vivid color is evident in her spring/summer 2016 collection, where hues of orange and blue pop.

Currently, Schnabl is in the process of reexamining and shifting her artistic practice, as she considers moving away from the restrictions of creating two collections a year. Her current atelier in Old Town is being phased out. This studio space is where she and Birgit Rohm, CEO and Co-Founder, have hosted numerous events for the fashion community. Although these events were integral to the company and the broader Chicago fashion public, Schnabl is interested in refocusing on design and artistic collaborations now. She admits the challenges faced by fashion designers in a non-fashion center like Chicago, from the loss of manufacturing to a lack of resources and relevance, are sometimes daunting. Neither of the two major newspapers pays fashion any mind.

She is using this time not only to shift potential modes of production, but also to reflect. “I want to explore how fashion can engage differently within a place. I’m very passionate about my work and I’m interested in what would truly be alternative modes of creating relationships through fashion,” she says. Ultimately, better problems and questions are what Schnabl is looking for, how to invest in the fashion moment, the Chicago moment, to design the constellation within which the garment can exist and have a complexity. As for getting to these moments, problems, questions, and constellations through her design process, Schnabl quotes the French proverb, “l’appétit vient en mangeant” (appetite comes with eating). By designing, creativity grows and the practice evolves and progresses, so she keeps some things unfinished, allowing the ideas to be harnessed for a future collection. “There’s nothing I’d rather do in my life than go to my studio and come up with an expression for a moment.”
